title: 1.0-UT-Q4
text: Use the table in the image.  What is the best estimate of $$\lim_{x\to 2} g(x)?$$
explanation: As $x$ gets closer to $2$ from the left, $g(x)$ is near $4$, and from the right, $g(x)$ is also near $4$. Both sides approach $4$, so the best estimate is $4.0$.

title: 1.0-UT-Q10
text: Use the graph in the image.  At $x=1$, what type of discontinuity does $h(x)$ have?
explanation: From the graph, as $x\to 1^-$, $h(x)\to 2$ (open circle). As $x\to 1^+$, $h(x)\to 3$ (right-hand segment). Since the one-sided limits are finite but unequal, the discontinuity is a jump discontinuity.
options: A: Removable discontinuity | B: Jump discontinuity | C: Infinite discontinuity | D: No discontinuity (continuous)

title: 1.0-UT-Q18
text: Use the graph in the image.  The function $p(x)$ is continuous on $[0,3]$. Based on the graph, which value is guaranteed to be attained by $p(x)$ for some $c\in(0,3)$?
explanation: Because $p$ is continuous on $[0,3]$, it satisfies IVT. The graph indicates $p(0)<0$ and $p(3)>0$, so $0$ lies between them. Therefore there must exist $c\in(0,3)$ such that $p(c)=0$.
options: A: -2 | B: There is not enough information to guarantee any value. | C: 6 | D: 0

title: 1.3-P1
text: Use the graph to evaluate the limit.  Find $\displaystyle \lim_{x\to 2^-} f(x)$.
explanation: As $x\to 2^-$, the graph follows the left branch. The $y$-values approach $3$ (the open circle at $(2,3)$). Therefore, $\lim_{x\to 2^-} f(x)=3$.
options: A: The limit does not exist | B: $4$ | C: $3$ | D: $2$

title: 1.3-P2
text: Use the graph to evaluate the limit.  Find $\displaystyle \lim_{x\to 1} f(x)$.
correct: A: The limit does not exist
explanation: From the left, $f(x)$ approaches $3$ (open circle at $(1,3)$). From the right, $f(x)$ approaches $1$ (horizontal segment). Since $\lim_{x\to 1^-} f(x)\neq \lim_{x\to 1^+} f(x)$, $\lim_{x\to 1} f(x)$ does not exist.
options: A: The limit does not exist | B: $3$ | C: $1$ | D: $2$

title: 1.3-P3
text: Use the graph to evaluate the limit.  Find $\displaystyle \lim_{x\to 0^+} f(x)$.
explanation: Near $x=0$ on the right, the graph shoots upward without bound. Therefore, $\lim_{x\to 0^+} f(x)=\infty$.
options: A: $-\infty$ | B: $0$ | C: $\infty$ | D: The limit does not exist

title: 1.3-P4
text: Use the graph to evaluate the limit.  Find $\displaystyle \lim_{x\to -1} f(x)$.
explanation: Approaching $x=-1$ from either side, the graph stays at $y=1$. Even though there is a hole at $(-1,1)$, the approaching value is $1$, so $\lim_{x\to -1} f(x)=1$.
options: A: The limit does not exist | B: $1$ | C: $-1$ | D: $0$

title: 1.3-P5
text: Use the graph to evaluate the limit.  Find $\displaystyle \lim_{x\to 0^+} f(x)$.
explanation: The graph is defined for $x\ge 0$ and approaches the point $(0,0)$ from the right. Therefore, $\lim_{x\to 0^+} f(x)=0$.
options: A: $1$ | B: $\infty$ | C: The limit does not exist | D: $0$

title: 1.5-P2
text: Using the graph (see image 1.5-P2.png), evaluate $$\lim_{x\to 1}\left(3f(x)-2g(x)\right).$$
explanation: From the graph, $$\lim_{x\to 1}f(x)=2,\quad \lim_{x\to 1}g(x)=-1.$$ By limit laws, $$\lim_{x\to 1}(3f(x)-2g(x))=3\cdot 2-2\cdot(-1)=8.$$
options: A: $8$ | B: $4$ | C: $-8$ | D: Does not exist

title: 1.6-P5
text: A function has the graph shown (see image 1.6-P5.png). What value should be defined at $x=3$ to make the function continuous at $x=3$?
explanation: To make $f$ continuous at $x=3$, define $f(3)$ to equal the two-sided limit. The graph shows a hole at $(3,6)$, so $$\lim_{x\to 3}f(x)=6$$ and the required definition is $f(3)=6$.
options: A: $3$ | B: $0$ | C: $6$ | D: No value works

title: 1.7-P1
text: Use the graph of $f$ to evaluate $\lim_{x\to -1} f(x)$. [image:1.7-P1.png]
explanation: Near $x=-1$, the curve follows the line segment on both sides and approaches the open-circle height. The filled point at $x=-1$ changes $f(-1)$ but not the limit.
options: A: DNE because there is a hole | B: $2$ | C: $\tfrac{1}{2}$ | D: DNE because there is a jump

title: 1.8-P2
text: The graph shows three functions near $x=0$: $y=-|x|$, $y=x\sin(\frac{1}{x})$, and $y=|x|$. What is $\lim_{x\to 0} x\sin(\frac{1}{x})$? [image:1.8-P2.png]
explanation: Since $-1\le \sin(\frac{1}{x})\le 1$, we have $-|x|\le x\sin(\frac{1}{x})\le |x|$. As $x\to 0$, both $-|x|$ and $|x|$ approach $0$, so by the Squeeze Theorem the limit is $0$.
options: A: $0$ | B: DNE | C: $1$ | D: The limit depends on the path to $0$

title: 1.8-P3
text: The graph shows $g(x)=\sin(\frac{1}{x})$ near $x=0$. What is $\lim_{x\to 0} g(x)$? [image:1.8-P3.png]
explanation: Even though $-1\le \sin(\frac{1}{x})\le 1$, the bounds do not squeeze to a single value. Near $0$, the function attains values arbitrarily close to many numbers in $[-1,1]$, so the limit does not exist.

title: 1.9-P1
text: The graph of $f$ is shown in the figure labeled 1.9-P1. What is $\lim_{x\to 2} f(x)$?
explanation: Read the approach values on both sides of $x=2$. The left-hand limit is $3$ and the right-hand limit is also $3$, so $\lim_{x\to 2} f(x)=3$.
options: A: $3$ | B: $1$ | C: Does not exist | D: $2$

title: 1.9-P4
text: The table shown in the figure labeled 1.9-P4 gives values of $f(x)$ near $x=2$. Estimate $\lim_{x\to 2} f(x)$.
explanation: As $x$ gets closer to $2$ from both sides, the function values get closer to $4$, so $\lim_{x\to 2} f(x)\approx 4$.
options: A: $3.61$ | B: $4$ | C: $4.41$ | D: Does not exist

title: 1.10-P1
text: The graph of $f$ is shown in the figure labeled 1.10-P1. What type of discontinuity does $f$ have at $x=1$?
explanation: At $x=1$, the function approaches one finite value from the left and a different finite value from the right, so the discontinuity is a jump discontinuity.
options: A: Removable discontinuity | B: Jump discontinuity | C: No discontinuity | D: Infinite discontinuity

title: 1.10-P3
text: The graph of $f$ is shown in the figure labeled 1.10-P3. Which statement is true about limits near $x=0$?
explanation: From the graph, as $x\to 0^-$ the function decreases without bound, and as $x\to 0^+$ it increases without bound. Therefore $\lim_{x\to 0^-} f(x)=-\infty$ and $\lim_{x\to 0^+} f(x)=+\infty$.
options: A: $\lim_{x\to 0^-} f(x)=-\infty$ and $\lim_{x\to 0^+} f(x)=+\i | B: $\lim_{x\to 0^-} f(x)=+\infty$ and $\lim_{x\to 0^+} f(x)=+\i | C: $\lim_{x\to 0} f(x)=0$ | D: $\lim_{x\to 0} f(x)$ exists and is finite

title: 1.11-P2
text: Use the graph (image). At $x=2$, which statement is true?  I. $\lim_{x\to 2} f(x)$ exists.  II. $f(2)$ exists.  III. $f$ is continuous at $x=2$.
explanation: From the graph, there is a filled point at $x=2$, so $f(2)$ exists. The value approached from the left differs from the value approached from the right, so $\lim_{x\to 2} f(x)$ does not exist. Without the limit, $f$ cannot be continuous at $x=2$.
options: A: I only | B: I and II only | C: II only | D: I, II, and III

title: 1.12-P3
text: Use the graph (image). On which set is $f$ continuous?
explanation: The graph shows a discontinuity at $x=1$ (the approached value(s) at $x=1$ do not agree with the function value). On each side of $1$, the graph is unbroken. Therefore $f$ is continuous on $[0,1)\cup(1,4]$.

title: 1.15-P2
text: The table shows values of $f(x)=\dfrac{3x^2+1}{x^2-4}$ for large $x$. See image: 1.15-P2.png Based on end behavior, which horizontal asymptote is correct?
explanation: For $$f(x)=\frac{3x^2+1}{x^2-4},$$ the degrees match, so $$\lim_{x\to\pm\infty} f(x)=\frac{3}{1}=3.$$ Thus the horizontal asymptote is $y=3$.
options: A: $y=-3$ | B: $y=3$ | C: $y=0$ | D: No horizontal asymptote

title: 1.15-P3
text: A graph is shown. See image: 1.15-P3.png What is $$\lim_{x\to\infty} f(x)?$$
explanation: From the graph, as $x$ increases without bound, the curve approaches the horizontal line $y=1$. Therefore, $$\lim_{x\to\infty} f(x)=1.$$
options: A: $0$ | B: $2$ | C: $1$ | D: Does not exist

title: 1.16-P3
text: A continuous function $y=f(x)$ is graphed, and the line $y=2$ is shown. See image: 1.16-P3.png Which statement is guaranteed by the Intermediate Value Theorem?
explanation: Because the curve is continuous and it crosses the horizontal line $y=2$, there is at least one point $c$ where $f(c)=2$. IVT justifies existence on any interval whose endpoints have function values on opposite sides of $2$.
options: A: There exists $c$ such that $f(c)=0$. | B: There exists $c$ such that $f(c)=5$. | C: There exists $c$ such that $f(c)=2$. | D: $f$ must be differentiable everywhere shown.

title: 1.16-P5
text: A graph of $y=g(x)$ is shown. See image: 1.16-P5.png Which statement is correct?
correct: D: IVT cannot be used on $[0,4]$ because $g$ is not continuous on that interval.
explanation: The graph shows a removable discontinuity (a hole) at $x=2$. Since $g$ is not continuous on $[0,4]$, the Intermediate Value Theorem cannot be applied on that interval.
options: A: IVT guarantees that $g(x)$ takes every value between $0$ and | B: $g$ is continuous on $[0,4]$ because the left and right side | C: IVT guarantees there exists $c\in(0,4)$ such that $g(c)=1$. | D: IVT cannot be used on $[0,4]$ because $g$ is not continuous

title: 2.0-UT-Q3
text: Use the graph (with two marked points). What is the slope of the secant line through the two marked points?
explanation: From the graph, the marked points are $(1,1)$ and $(3,5)$. The secant slope is $$\frac{5-1}{3-1}=2.$$

title: 2.0-UT-Q6
text: Use the table to estimate $f'(2)$ using a symmetric difference.
explanation: A symmetric difference around $2$ gives $$f'(2)\approx \frac{f(2.01)-f(1.99)}{2.01-1.99}=\frac{4.0401-3.9601}{0.02}=4.$$

title: 2.0-UT-Q8
text: Use the graph of $y=|x|$. Which statement is true about the derivative at $x=0$?
correct: B: The derivative does not exist at $x=0$.
explanation: $|x|$ is continuous at $0$ but not differentiable there because the one-sided slopes differ ($-1$ vs $1$).
options: A: The derivative exists and equals $0$. | B: The derivative does not exist at $x=0$. | C: The derivative exists and equals $-1$. | D: The derivative exists and equals $1$.

title: 2.0-UT-Q14
text: Use the graph of $y=\sin x$ with a dashed tangent line at $x=0$. What is $\sin'(0)$?
explanation: $(\sin x)'=\cos x$, so $\sin'(0)=\cos 0=1$.

title: 2.3-P1
text: Use the graph (see image) to best estimate $f'(2)$. The point $(2, f(2))$ is marked on the curve.
explanation: The derivative at a point is the slope of the tangent line. From the graph near $x=2$, the rise over run over a small interval (e.g., from $x=1.5$ to $x=2.5$) suggests an average slope close to $2$.
options: A: About $1.2$ | B: About $2$ | C: About $0.2$ | D: About $6$

title: 2.3-P4
text: A graph (see image) shows $y=f(x)$ and a symmetric secant line through the points at $x=1.0$ and $x=2.0$. Which value is the best estimate of $f'(1.5)$ using this symmetric secant?
explanation: A symmetric secant about $x=a$ uses points $a-h$ and $a+h$: $$f'(a) \approx \frac{f(a+h)-f(a-h)}{2h}$$ Here $a=1.5$ and the points are $1.0$ and $2.0$ (so $h=0.5$). Thus, $$f'(1.5) \approx \frac{f(2.0)-f(1.0)}{2.0-1.0} = \frac{f(2.0)-f(1.0)}{1.0}$$

title: 2.4-P5
text: A function $f$ has the graph shown (see image), with $f(0) = 1$. Which statement is true about $f$ at $x=0$?
correct: C: $f$ is continuous but not differentiable at $x=0$
explanation: From the graph, the two pieces meet at $x=0$, so $\lim_{x\to 0} f(x) = f(0)$ and $f$ is continuous. The one-sided slopes at $x=0$ do not match, so $f$ is not differentiable at $x=0$.
options: A: $f$ is differentiable at $x=0$ | B: $f$ is not continuous at $x=0$ but is differentiable at $x=0 | C: $f$ is continuous but not differentiable at $x=0$ | D: $f$ is neither continuous nor differentiable at $x=0$

title: 3.0-UT-Q3
text: Given $x^2+y^2=25$, find $\frac{dy}{dx}$ in terms of $x$ and $y$.
explanation: Differentiate implicitly: $$2x+2y\frac{dy}{dx}=0\Rightarrow \frac{dy}{dx}=-\frac{x}{y}.$$

title: 3.0-UT-Q5
text: Use the graph of $y=f(x)$ and its tangent line at $(1,2)$ (see image). What is $(f^{-1})'(2)$?
explanation: From the tangent line in the image, $f'(1)=-2$ and $f(1)=2$. Therefore, $$(f^{-1})'(2)=\frac{1}{f'(1)}=\frac{1}{-2}=-\frac{1}{2}.$$

title: 3.0-UT-Q17
text: The curve is $x^2+xy+y^2=7$ with the point $(2,1)$ marked (see image). What is the slope of the tangent line at $(2,1)$?
explanation: Differentiate: $$2x+\frac{d}{dx}(xy)+2y\frac{dy}{dx}=0,\quad \frac{d}{dx}(xy)=y+x\frac{dy}{dx}.$$ So $$(2x+y)+(x+2y)\frac{dy}{dx}=0.$$ At $(2,1)$: $$5+4\frac{dy}{dx}=0\Rightarrow \frac{dy}{dx}=-\frac{5}{4}.$$

title: 3.3-P2
text: The graph of a one-to-one function $y=f(x)$ and the line $y=x$ are shown in the figure labeled 3.3-P2. The point $(2,3)$ lies on $y=f(x)$ and $f'(2)=6$. What is $(f^{-1})'(3)$?

title: 3.4-P3
text: The graph of $y=\arctan(x)$ is shown in the figure labeled 3.4-P3, with the point $(1,\arctan(1))$ marked. What is the slope of the tangent line at $x=1$?
explanation: Since $\dfrac{d}{dx}\arctan(x)=\dfrac{1}{1+x^2}$, evaluate at $x=1$: $$\arctan'(1)=\frac{1}{1+1^2}=\frac{1}{2}.$$

title: 3.6-P5
text: Use the graph of $f'(x)$ to determine where $f$ is concave down. (See image.)
explanation: $f$ is concave down where $f''(x)<0$, i.e., where $f'(x)$ is decreasing. From the graph, $f'(x)$ decreases on $(-2,2)$ and increases on $(2,4)$. Among the choices, the interval fully contained in the decreasing region is $(-2,1)$.

title: 4.0-UT-Q2
text: The image shows position $s$ (meters) versus time $t$ (seconds). At $t=5$, which best describes the velocity $v(5)$? (See image.)
explanation: Velocity is $v(t)=s'(t)$, the slope of the position–time graph. At $t=5$ the curve is increasing, so $s'(5)>0$.
options: A: $v(5)<0$ | B: $v(5)=0$ | C: $v(5)>0$ | D: Velocity cannot be determined from a position–time graph.

title: 4.0-UT-Q9
text: A $10$-ft ladder leans against a wall. Let $x$ be the distance (ft) from the wall to the foot of the ladder and $y$ the height (ft) of the top of the ladder. When $x=6$ and $\frac{dx}{dt}=2$ ft/s, wha
explanation: Using $x^2+y^2=100$, differentiate: $2x\frac{dx}{dt}+2y\frac{dy}{dt}=0$, so $\frac{dy}{dt}=-\frac{x}{y}\frac{dx}{dt}$. When $x=6$, $y=\sqrt{100-36}=8$, so $\frac{dy}{dt}=-\frac{6}{8}(2)=-\frac{3}{4}$ ft/s.

title: 4.1-P3
text: Refer to the graph. The temperature $T$ of a chemical bath (in $^\circ\!\text{C}$) is shown as a function of time $t$ (in hours). A tangent line is drawn at $t=3$. Which value best estimates $T'(3)$?
explanation: The derivative at $t=3$ is the slope of the tangent line. From the drawn tangent, the rise is roughly $1.2\\ ^\circ\!\text{C}$ over a run of about $1.2$ hours, giving a slope near $1\\ ^\circ\!\text{C}/\text{hour}$.
options: A: About $1.0\\ ^\circ\!\text{C}/\text{hour}$ | B: About $0.1\\ ^\circ\!\text{C}/\text{hour}$ | C: About $10\\ ^\circ\!\text{C}/\text{hour}$ | D: About $-1.0\\ ^\circ\!\text{C}/\text{hour}$

title: 4.2-P2
text: Refer to the position graph (velocity is slope). What is the cart's velocity at $t = 6$ seconds?
explanation: Velocity is the slope of the position graph. At $t=6$, the cart lies on the segment from $(5, 6)$ to $(7, 2)$, so $m = \frac{2-6}{7-5} = -2$ m/s.

title: 4.2-P5
text: Refer to the velocity graph. Which value best represents the drone's acceleration at $t=2$ seconds?
explanation: Acceleration is the slope of the velocity graph. The graph is a straight line, so acceleration is constant: $$a=\frac{10-(-2)}{8-0}=\frac{12}{8}=1.5\\ \text{m/s}^2.$$

title: 4.3-P5
text: A tank’s volume $V(t)$ (in liters) changes due to inflow and outflow. Inflow is $8\ \mathrm{L/min}$. Outflow is $2\sqrt{V}\ \mathrm{L/min}$. At the instant when $V=25$, what is $\dfrac{dV}{dt}$?
explanation: Net rate is inflow minus outflow: $\dfrac{dV}{dt}=8-2\sqrt{V}$. At $V=25$, $\dfrac{dV}{dt}=8-2\cdot 5=-2\ \mathrm{L/min}$.

title: 4.4-P3
text: A $10$-ft ladder leans against a vertical wall. The bottom slides away from the wall at $\dfrac{dx}{dt}=2\ \mathrm{ft/s}$. At the instant when $x=6\ \mathrm{ft}$, what is $\dfrac{dy}{dt}$, where $y$ i
explanation: Constraint: $x^2+y^2=100$. Differentiate: $2x\dfrac{dx}{dt}+2y\dfrac{dy}{dt}=0\Rightarrow \dfrac{dy}{dt}=-\dfrac{x}{y}\dfrac{dx}{dt}$. When $x=6$, $y=\sqrt{100-36}=8$, so $\dfrac{dy}{dt}=-(\frac{6}{8})(2)=-1.5\ \mathrm{ft/s}$.

title: 4.4-P4
text: Two variables satisfy $x^2+xy=10$, where $x$ and $y$ are functions of time $t$. If $\dfrac{dx}{dt}=1$ and at the instant $x=2$ and $y=3$, what is $\dfrac{dy}{dt}$?
explanation: Differentiate: $\dfrac{d}{dt}(x^2)+\dfrac{d}{dt}(xy)=0\Rightarrow 2x\dfrac{dx}{dt}+x\dfrac{dy}{dt}+y\dfrac{dx}{dt}=0$. Substitute $x=2$, $y=3$, $\frac{dx}{dt}=1$: $4+2\,\frac{dy}{dt}+3=0\Rightarrow \frac{dy}{dt}=\frac{-7}{2}$.

title: 4.6-P2
text: The graph shows $f(x)=\sqrt{x+1}$ and the tangent line at $x=3$ (see image). Use the tangent line (linearization at $x=3$) to approximate $\sqrt{4.1}$.
explanation: Write $\sqrt{4.1}=\sqrt{(3.1)+1}=f(3.1)$ for $f(x)=\sqrt{x+1}$. Linearization at $a=3$: $$L(x)=f(3)+f'(3)(x-3).$$ Compute $f(3)=2$ and $$f'(x)=\frac{1}{2\sqrt{x+1}}\;\Rightarrow\; f'(3)=\frac{1}{4}.$$ Then $$\sqrt{4.1}=f(3.1)\approx L(3.1)=2+\frac{1}

title: 5.0-UT-Q1
text: IMAGE: unit_test-P1.png  The secant line between $x=0.8$ and $x=3.8$ has slope $2$. Assume $f$ is continuous on $[0.8,3.8]$ and differentiable on $(0.8,3.8)$. Which statement must be true?
explanation: By the Mean Value Theorem, there exists $c$ such that $$f'(c)=\frac{f(3.8)-f(0.8)}{3.8-0.8}=2.$$
options: A: Both B and C must occur | B: There exists $c$ with $f'(c)>2$ | C: There exists $c$ with $f'(c)<2$ | D: There exists $c$ with $f'(c)=2$

title: 5.0-UT-Q7
text: IMAGE: unit_test-P7.png  The graph shown is $f'(x)$. On which interval is $f$ decreasing?
explanation: $f$ is decreasing where $f'(x)<0$. From the graph, $f'(x)$ is negative on $(-1,2)$, so $f$ is decreasing on $(-1,2)$.
options: A: $(-\infty,-1)$ | B: $(2,\infty)$ | C: $(-1,2)$ | D: None; $f$ is increasing for all $x$.

title: 5.0-UT-Q10
text: IMAGE: unit_test-P10.png  The graph shown is $f''(x)$. On which interval is $f$ concave down?
explanation: $f$ is concave down where $f''(x)<0$. From the graph, $f''(x)$ is negative on $(1,3)$, so $f$ is concave down on $(1,3)$.
options: A: All real $x$ | B: $(-\infty,1)$ | C: $(3,\infty)$ | D: $(1,3)$

title: 5.2-P3
text: The graph of $f$ on $[-1,3]$ is shown in the provided image (5.2-P3.png). Which statement is supported by the graph?
correct: B: The absolute maximum occurs at an interior point near $x\approx 0.1$, and the ab

title: 5.3-P3
text: See image (5.3-P3.png). The graph shown is $y=f'(x)$. On which intervals is $f$ increasing?
explanation: A function $f$ is increasing where $f'(x)>0$. Reading the derivative graph, the curve is above the $x$-axis on $(-3,1)$ and on $(2,\infty)$, and below the $x$-axis on $(-\infty,-3)$ and $(1,2)$. Therefore $f$ is increasing on $(-3,1)\cup(2,\infty)$.

title: 5.4-P4
text: See image (5.4-P4.png). Based on the graph of $f(x)$, which statement about local extrema is correct?
correct: B: Local maximum at approximately $x=1$ and local minimum at approximately $x=3$

options: A: Local maxima at approximately $x=1$ and $x=3$ | B: Local maximum at approximately $x=1$ and local minimum at ap | C: Local minimum at approximately $x=1$ and local maximum at ap | D: No local extrema are shown

title: 5.5-P3
text: The graph of $f$ on $[0,4]$ is shown (see image: 5.5-P3.png). At approximately which $x$-value does $f$ attain its absolute maximum on $[0,4]$?
explanation: Absolute maximum on a closed interval occurs at the highest function value among endpoints and interior peaks/valleys. From the graph, the highest point is the interior peak near $x\approx 2.5$.

title: 5.6-P2
text: The sign chart for $f^{\prime\prime}(x)$ is shown (see image: 5.6-P2.png). On the interval $(-3,6)$, how many inflection points does $f$ have?
explanation: Inflection points occur where $f^{\prime\prime}$ changes sign. From the chart, the sign changes at $x=-1$ (from $+$ to $-$), at $x=2$ (from $-$ to $+$), and at $x=5$ (from $+$ to $-$). All are inside $(-3,6)$, so there are 3 inflection points.

title: 5.6-P5
text: The graph of $f^{\prime}(x)$ is shown for $-2\le x\le 6$ (see image: 5.6-P5.png). On which interval is $f$ concave up?
explanation: A function is concave up where $f^{\prime\prime}>0$, equivalently where $f^{\prime}$ is increasing. From the graph, $f^{\prime}(x)$ has its minimum at $x=\tfrac{5}{2}$ and increases for $x>\tfrac{5}{2}$. Thus $f$ is concave up on $(\tfrac{5}{2},6)$.

title: 5.8-P1
text: The image (5.8-P1.png) shows the graph of $f$. On which interval is $f'(x)>0$ for all $x$ in the interval?
explanation: Where a function is increasing, its derivative is positive. The graph increases continuously from the local minimum near $x=-1$ to the local maximum near $x=2$, so $f'(x)>0$ on $(-1,2)$.

title: 5.8-P2
text: The image (5.8-P2.png) shows the graph of $f'(x)$. At which $x$-value does $f$ have a local maximum?
explanation: A local maximum occurs where $f'(x)$ changes from $+$ to $-$. From the graph, this happens at $x=1$.

title: 5.8-P3
text: The image (5.8-P3.png) shows the graph of $f''(x)$. On which interval is $f$ concave down?
explanation: A function is concave down where $f''(x)<0$. From the graph of $f''$, it is negative on $(0,2)$.
options: A: $(0,2)$ | B: $(2,\infty)$ | C: $(-\infty,0)$ | D: All real numbers

title: 5.8-P4
text: Suppose $f(x)=x^3-3x^2+1$. The image (5.8-P4.png) shows four candidate graphs (A–D). Which candidate graph could represent $f'(x)$?
explanation: Differentiate: $f'(x)=3x^2-6x=3x(x-2)$. So $f'(x)$ is an upward-opening parabola crossing the $x$-axis at $0$ and $2$, which corresponds to option A.
options: A: D | B: B | C: C | D: A

title: 5.8-P5
text: The image (5.8-P5.png) shows the graph of $f$ and the tangent line at $x=2$. Which value is closest to $f'(2)$?
explanation: The derivative at a point equals the slope of the tangent line there. Reading two convenient points on the tangent line from the graph gives a slope near $0.29$.

title: 5.9-P1
text: The graph of $f'(x)$ is shown. At which $x$-value does $f$ have a local maximum?
explanation: A local maximum of $f$ occurs where $f'(x)=0$ and the sign of $f'(x)$ changes from positive to negative. From the graph, $f'(x)=0$ at $x=-1,\,\tfrac{5}{3},\,4$. Near $x=-1$, $f'(x)$ goes from $+$ to $-$, so $f$ has a local maximum at $x=-1$. Near $x=
options: A: $x=\dfrac{5}{3}$ only | B: Neither $x=-1$ nor $x=\dfrac{5}{3}$ | C: Both $x=-1$ and $x=\dfrac{5}{3}$ | D: $x=-1$ only

title: 5.9-P3
text: Three graphs (I, II, III) are shown. One is $f$, one is $f'$, and one is $f''$ for the same function $f$. Which matching is consistent?
correct: C: I is $f$, II is $f'$, III is $f''$
explanation: Graph I has even-degree end behavior (both ends up) and multiple turning points, consistent with a quartic-like $f$. Graph II has odd-degree end behavior and an S-shape, consistent with a cubic-like $f'$. Graph III is U-shaped, consistent with a quad
options: A: I is $f''$, II is $f'$, III is $f$ | B: I is $f'$, II is $f$, III is $f''$ | C: I is $f$, II is $f'$, III is $f''$ | D: I is $f$, II is $f''$, III is $f'$

title: 5.10-P2
text: An open-top box is made by cutting out squares of side length $x$ from each corner of a square sheet of side length $s$ and folding up the sides. Which expression gives the volume $V(x)$ of the box?
explanation: Cutting out squares of side $x$ makes the box height $x$. Each dimension of the base loses $x$ on both ends, so the base side length is $s-2x$. Base area is $(s-2x)^2$, so $V(x)=x(s-2x)^2$.

title: 5.11-P3
text: A $10\times 16$ rectangle of cardboard is used to make an open-top box by cutting out squares of side $x$ from each corner and folding up the sides. (See image.) What value of $x$ maximizes the volume
explanation: Volume is $$V(x)=x(10-2x)(16-2x),\quad 0<x<5.$$ Expanding: $$V(x)=4x^3-52x^2+160x,$$ so $$V'(x)=12x^2-104x+160=0\Rightarrow 3x^2-26x+40=0.$$ Thus $x=2$ or $x=\frac{20}{3}$, and only $x=2$ lies in $(0,5)$. Since endpoints give volume $0$, $x=2$ maximi

title: 5.12-P5
text: The graph shows the curve $x^2+y^2=4y$ with labeled points A, B, C, and D. At which labeled point is the tangent line vertical? (See image.)
explanation: For $x^2+y^2=4y$, $$y'=-\frac{2x}{2y-4}.$$ A vertical tangent occurs when $2y-4=0$ and $x\ne 0$, i.e., at points with $y=2$ on the curve. The labeled point with $y=2$ and $x\ne 0$ is A.
options: A: A | B: B | C: C | D: D

title: 6.0-UT-Q2
text: The diagram shows rectangles used to approximate $\int_0^4 \sqrt{x}\,dx$. Which expression matches the approximation shown?
explanation: The picture shows a left Riemann sum with $n=4$ on $[0,4]$. Thus $\Delta x=1$ and sample points are $0,1,2,3$: $$L_4=\Delta x\sum_{i=0}^{3}\sqrt{i}=1(\sqrt0+\sqrt1+\sqrt2+\sqrt3).$$

title: 6.0-UT-Q5
text: Let $F(x)=\int_0^x g(t)\,dt$. The graph of $g$ is shown. Which statement is true?
correct: C: There exists a point in $(2,3)$ where $F$ has a local maximum.
explanation: By FTC, $F'(x)=g(x)$. $F$ increases where $g>0$ and decreases where $g<0$. A local maximum of $F$ occurs where $g$ changes from positive to negative; the graph shows that change within $(2,3)$.
options: A: $F(4)<F(3)$. | B: $F$ is increasing on $(2,3)$. | C: There exists a point in $(2,3)$ where $F$ has a local maximu | D: If $g(2)=0$, then $F$ must have an inflection point at $x=2$

title: 6.0-UT-Q8
text: The shaded region is between $y=x$ and $y=x^2$ on $0\le x\le 1$. What is the area of the region?
explanation: On $[0,1]$, the top curve is $y=x$ and the bottom curve is $y=x^2$, so $$\text{Area}=\int_0^1 (x-x^2)\,dx=\left[\frac{x^2}{2}-\frac{x^3}{3}\right]_0^1=\frac16.$$

title: 6.0-UT-Q17
text: Consider $\int_0^4 \frac{1}{(x-2)^2}\,dx$. The graph of $y=\frac{1}{(x-2)^2}$ is shown. Which statement is true?
explanation: Split at the discontinuity: $$\int_0^4 \frac{1}{(x-2)^2}dx=\lim_{b\to2^-}\int_0^b\frac{1}{(x-2)^2}dx+\lim_{a\to2^+}\int_a^4\frac{1}{(x-2)^2}dx.$$ Each term diverges, so the integral diverges.
options: A: The integral equals $\left[-\frac{1}{x-2}\right]_0^4$. | B: The integral converges to $\frac12$. | C: The integral converges to $1$. | D: The integral diverges.

title: 6.3-P5
text: The graph of $f$ is shown in the figure labeled 6.3-P5, where $f(x)=\sqrt{x}$ on $[0,4]$ and the partition is $0,1,2.5,4$. Let $L$ be the left-endpoint Riemann sum and $R$ be the right-endpoint Rieman
explanation: Since $f(x)=\sqrt{x}$ is increasing on $[0,4]$, on each subinterval the left endpoint gives a smaller function value than the right endpoint. Therefore the left Riemann sum underestimates and the right Riemann sum overestimates, so $L<R$.
options: A: $L=R$ | B: $L>R$ | C: $L<R$ | D: Cannot be determined without computing $L$ and $R$ exactly.

title: 6.4-P5
text: The graph of $f$ is shown in the figure labeled 6.4-P5. The graph is piecewise linear through $(0,1)$, $(1,3)$, $(3,0)$, and $(4,-2)$. Define $A(x)=\int_{0}^{x} f(t)\,dt$. What is $A(4)$?
explanation: Compute signed areas. On $[0,1]$: trapezoid with bases $1$ and $3$, width $1$, area $\frac{1+3}{2}\cdot1=2$. On $[1,3]$: trapezoid with bases $3$ and $0$, width $2$, area $\frac{3+0}{2}\cdot2=3$. On $[3,4]$: trapezoid with bases $0$ and $-2$, width $

title: 6.5-P2
text: Let $A(x)=\displaystyle\int_{0}^{x} f(t)\,dt$, where $f$ is shown in the figure. Which statement about $A$ at $x=4$ is true?
correct: B: $A'(4)=0$ and $A$ has a local minimum at $x=4$.
explanation: FTC gives $A'(x)=f(x)$ and $A''(x)=f'(x)$. From the figure, $f(4)=0$ and $f'(4)>0$, so $A$ has a local minimum at $x=4$.
options: A: $A$ is increasing and concave down at $x=4$. | B: $A'(4)=0$ and $A$ has a local minimum at $x=4$. | C: $A$ has a local maximum at $x=4$. | D: $A$ is decreasing at $x=4$.

title: 6.5-P4
text: A tank contains $50$ gallons at $t=0$. Its volume is $V(t)=50+\displaystyle\int_{0}^{t} r(s)\,ds$, where $r(t)$ (in gallons per hour) is shown in the figure. What is $V(6)$?
explanation: Net change is the signed area under $r(t)$ from $0$ to $6$: $6+(-2)+4=8$. Add to the initial $50$ to get $58$.

title: 6.6-P5
text: The graph of an odd function $h$ is shown in the figure. What is $\displaystyle\int_{-3}^{3} h(x)\,dx$?
explanation: If $h$ is odd, then $h(-x)=-h(x)$, so areas cancel on $[-3,3]$ and the integral equals $0$.
options: A: $6$ | B: $-6$ | C: $0$ | D: Cannot be determined without an equation for $h$.

title: 6.7-P1
text: The graph of $f$ is shown. What is the value of $\int_{0}^{4} f(x)\,dx$?
explanation: Compute the signed area under $f$ from $0$ to $4$ using geometry. From $0$ to $1$, the region is a triangle with base $1$ and height $2$, so area $=\tfrac12(1)(2)=1$. From $1$ to $3$, the region is a rectangle of width $2$ and height $2$, so area $=4

title: 7.0-UT-Q3
text: The image shows the slope field for $\dfrac{dy}{dx}=x-y$. At the point $(1,0)$, which slope best matches the field?  ![7.0-UT-Q3](7.0-UT-Q3.png)
explanation: Compute the slope from the DE: $\dfrac{dy}{dx}=x-y$. At $(1,0)$, the slope is $1$.

title: 7.0-UT-Q15
text: Use Euler’s method with step size $h=0.5$ to approximate $y(1.5)$ for $y''=y-x$, $y(0)=1$.  ![7.0-UT-Q15](7.0-UT-Q15.png)

title: 7.3-P2
text: Use the accompanying slope field (image). At the point $(1,0)$, which value best matches the slope $\dfrac{dy}{dx}$ indicated by the field?
explanation: Reading the segment at $(1,0)$, the local tilt is closest to slope $1$.

title: 7.4-P1
text: Use the accompanying slope field (image). A solution satisfies $y(0)=0.5$. As $x\to\infty$, what value does $y$ approach?
explanation: From the field, $y=0$ and $y=2$ are equilibrium lines. In the region $0<y<2$ the slopes are positive, so the solution increases toward the stable equilibrium $y=2$.

title: 7.4-P4
text: Use the accompanying slope field (image). Which statement about the equilibrium solution $y=0$ is correct?
correct: D: $y=0$ is stable because nearby solutions move toward it as $x$ increases.
explanation: The field shows horizontal segments on $y=0$. For $y>0$ the slopes are negative and for $y<0$ the slopes are positive, so solutions move toward $y=0$ as $x$ increases. Therefore $y=0$ is stable.
options: A: $y=0$ is unstable because nearby solutions move away from it | B: $y=0$ is neither stable nor unstable because slopes are zero | C: $y=0$ is not an equilibrium because the solution curve must  | D: $y=0$ is stable because nearby solutions move toward it as $

title: 8.0-UT-Q4
text: The shaded region between $y=\sin x$ and $y=\cos x$ on $[0,\frac{\pi}{2}]$ is shown in 8.0-UT-Q4.png. Which expression equals the area of the region?
explanation: Solve $\sin x=\cos x$ to find the switch point $x=\frac{\pi}{4}$. On $[0,\frac{\pi}{4}]$, top is $\cos x$; on $[\frac{\pi}{4},\frac{\pi}{2}]$, top is $\sin x$. Therefore $$A=\int_0^{\frac{\pi}{4}}(\cos x-\sin x)\,dx+\int_{\frac{\pi}{4}}^{\frac{\pi}{2
options: A: $\int_0^{\frac{\pi}{2}}(\sin x-\cos x)\,dx$ | B: $\int_0^{\frac{\pi}{2}}|\sin x-\cos x|\,dx$ | C: $\int_0^{\frac{\pi}{4}}(\cos x-\sin x)\,dx+\int_{\frac{\pi}{ | D: $\int_0^{\frac{\pi}{4}}(\sin x-\cos x)\,dx+\int_{\frac{\pi}{

title: 8.0-UT-Q5
text: The region bounded by $x=y^2$ and $x=2y$ is shown in 8.0-UT-Q5.png. Which integral gives the area of the region?
explanation: Find intersections: $y^2=2y\Rightarrow y=0,2$. Using horizontal slices, $$A=\int_{0}^{2}\big(x_{right}-x_{left}\big)\,dy=\int_0^2(2y-y^2)\,dy.$$

title: 8.0-UT-Q7
text: A solid has base region bounded by $y=\sqrt{x}$, $y=0$, and $0\le x\le 4$ (shown in 8.0-UT-Q7.png). Cross-sections perpendicular to the $x$-axis are squares. What is the volume?
explanation: Square cross-sectional area is $A(x)=(\text{side})^2=(\sqrt{x})^2=x$. Thus $$V=\int_0^4 A(x)\,dx=\int_0^4 x\,dx=\left[\frac{x^2}{2}\right]_0^4=8.$$

title: 8.0-UT-Q9
text: The region under $y=2-x$ above the $x$-axis for $0\le x\le 2$ is shown in 8.0-UT-Q9.png. It is revolved about the $y$-axis. Which integral gives the volume using the disc/washer method?
explanation: Write the boundary as $x=2-y$ for $0\le y\le 2$. Revolving about the $y$-axis gives discs of radius $R(y)=2-y$: $$V=\pi\int_0^2(2-y)^2\,dy.$$

title: 8.0-UT-Q10
text: The region under $y=x^2$ above the $x$-axis on $0\le x\le 1$ is shown in 8.0-UT-Q10.png. It is revolved about the vertical line $x=1$. Which integral gives the volume using washers?
explanation: Washers about a vertical line use $dy$. Since $y=x^2$, we have $x=\sqrt{y}$ for $0\le y\le 1$. The radius to $x=1$ is $R(y)=1-\sqrt{y}$, so $$V=\pi\int_0^1(1-\sqrt{y})^2\,dy.$$

title: 8.0-UT-Q12
text: The region between $y=x$ and $y=x^2$ on $0\le x\le 1$ is shown in 8.0-UT-Q12.png. It is revolved about $y=3$. Which integral gives the volume?
explanation: Distances to $y=3$ give radii. Since $x^2\le x$ on $[0,1]$, the lower curve is $y=x^2$ and is farther from $y=3$, so $R=3-x^2$ and $r=3-x$. $$V=\pi\int_0^1\left((3-x^2)^2-(3-x)^2\right)dx.$$

title: 8.0-UT-Q16
text: The graph of $y=\sin x$ on $[0,2\pi]$ is shown in 8.0-UT-Q16.png. Which integral equals the total area between the curve and the $x$-axis on $[0,2\pi]$?
explanation: Because $\sin x$ changes sign, total area is $$A=\int_0^{2\pi}|\sin x|\,dx.$$
options: A: $\int_0^{2\pi}\sin x\,dx$ | B: $\int_0^{\pi}\sin x\,dx$ | C: $\int_0^{2\pi}|\sin x|\,dx$ | D: $\int_0^{\pi}|\sin x|\,dx$

title: 8.0-UT-Q19
text: The curve $y=\ln x$ on $[1,e]$ is shown in 8.0-UT-Q19.png. Which integral gives the exact arc length from $x=1$ to $x=e$?
explanation: For $y=f(x)$, arc length is $\int_a^b\sqrt{1+(f'(x))^2}dx$. Here $f(x)=\ln x$ so $f'(x)=\frac{1}{x}$, giving $$L=\int_1^e\sqrt{1+\frac{1}{x^2}}\,dx.$$

title: 8.1-P2
text: The graph of $f$ on $[0,4]$ is shown in the figure labeled 8.1-P2. Which expression equals the average value of $f$ on $[0,4]$?
explanation: For any function (graph or formula), the average value on $[a,b]$ is $$f_{\mathrm{avg}}=\frac{1}{b-a}\int_a^b f(x)\,dx.$$ With $a=0$ and $b=4$, this is $\frac{1}{4}\int_0^4 f(x)\,dx$.
options: A: $\displaystyle \frac{1}{4}\int_0^4 f(x)\,dx$ | B: $\displaystyle \int_0^4 f(x)\,dx$ | C: $\displaystyle \frac{1}{f(4)-f(0)}\int_0^4 f(x)\,dx$ | D: $\displaystyle \frac{f(4)-f(0)}{4}$

title: 8.2-P2
text: The velocity of a particle is shown in the figure labeled 8.2-P2. What is the total distance traveled on $0\le t\le 9$?
explanation: Total distance traveled is $$\int_0^9 |v(t)|\,dt.$$ From the step graph: $v=1$ on $[0,5)$ gives $5$, $v=-2$ on $[5,7)$ gives $4$, and $v=0$ on $[7,9]$ gives $0$, so the total distance is $9$.

title: 8.3-P2
text: See image: 8.3-P2.png. A tank initially contains $10$ liters of water. The net flow rate (in liters per hour) is $r(t)$ as shown. What is the amount of water in the tank at $t=8$ hours?
explanation: Compute net change by signed areas under the step graph. From $0$ to $2$: $3\cdot2=6$. From $2$ to $4$: $3\cdot2=6$. From $4$ to $6$: $(-1)\cdot2=-2$. From $6$ to $8$: $2\cdot2=4$. Net change $=6+6-2+4=14$ liters. Final amount $=10+14=24$ liters.

title: 8.4-P4
text: See image: 8.4-P4.png. The curves are $y=(x-1)^2$ and $y=3-x$. What is the area of the region enclosed by these two curves?
explanation: Find intersections: $(x-1)^2=3-x\Rightarrow x^2-2x+1=3-x\Rightarrow x^2-x-2=0\Rightarrow x=-1,2$. On $[-1,2]$, the line is above the parabola (e.g., at $x=0$, $3>1$). Area: $$\int_{-1}^{2}\big((3-x)-(x-1)^2\big)\,dx=\int_{-1}^{2} (2+x-x^2)\,dx.$$ An

title: 8.4-P5
text: See image: 8.4-P5.png. What is the area of the region enclosed by $y=\sqrt{x}$ and $y=\frac{x}{2}$?
explanation: Solve intersections: $\sqrt{x}=\frac{x}{2}\Rightarrow 2\sqrt{x}=x\Rightarrow x=0$ or (for $x\ne0$) $2=\sqrt{x}\Rightarrow x=4$. On $[0,4]$, $\sqrt{x}\ge \frac{x}{2}$. Area: $$\int_0^4\left(\sqrt{x}-\frac{x}{2}\right)dx=\left[\frac{2}{3}x^{\frac{3}{2}

title: 8.5-P2
text: The shaded region is bounded by $x=y^2-1$ and $x=3-y$ (see image). Which integral equals the area of the shaded region?  ![8.5-P2](8.5-P2.png)
explanation: Because both boundaries are given as $x$ in terms of $y$, use horizontal slices. Let $y_1<y_2$ be the intersection $y$-values found from $y^2-1=3-y$. For each $y$ between $y_1$ and $y_2$, the right boundary is $x=3-y$ and the left boundary is $x=y^2-

title: 8.5-P5
text: The region $R$ is bounded by $y=2x$ and $y=x^2$ (see image). Using integration with respect to $y$, what is the area of $R$?  ![8.5-P5](8.5-P5.png)
explanation: Intersections: $2x=x^2\Rightarrow x=0,2$, giving $y=0,4$. Solve for $x$ in terms of $y$: From $y=2x$, $x=\frac{y}{2}$. From $y=x^2$ in the region, $x=\sqrt{y}$. For $0\le y\le 4$, $\frac{y}{2}\le \sqrt{y}$, so left is $x=\frac{y}{2}$ and right is $x=

title: 8.6-P3
text: Find the area between $y=\sin x$ and $y=0$ on $[0,2\pi]$ (see image).  ![8.6-P3](8.6-P3.png)
explanation: Geometric area is $$A=\int_0^{2\pi}|\sin x|\,dx=\int_0^{\pi}\sin x\,dx+\int_{\pi}^{2\pi}(-\sin x)\,dx.$$ Compute: $$\int_0^{\pi}\sin x\,dx=[-\cos x]_0^{\pi}=2,$$ $$\int_{\pi}^{2\pi}(-\sin x)\,dx=[\cos x]_{\pi}^{2\pi}=2.$$ So $A=4$.

title: 8.9-P2
text: The graph of the region bounded by $y=x^2$, $y=0$, and $x=1$ is shown in the figure labeled 8.9-P2. The region is revolved about the $y$-axis. Using the disc method, what is the volume of the solid?
explanation: For rotation about the $y$-axis using discs, take horizontal slices. Rewrite $y=x^2$ as $x=\sqrt{y}$. Radius is $r(y)=\sqrt{y}$ for $0\le y\le 1. $$V=\pi\int_0^1 r(y)^2\,dy=\pi\int_0^1 y\,dy=\pi\left[\frac{y^2}{2}\right]_0^1=\frac{\pi}{2}.$$

title: 8.9-P4
text: The graph of the region bounded by $y=\ln x$, $y=0$, $x=1$, and $x=e$ is shown in the figure labeled 8.9-P4. The region is revolved about the $x$-axis. What is the volume of the resulting solid?
explanation: Disc method about the $x$-axis gives $$V=\pi\int_1^{e} (\ln x)^2\,dx.$$ Use $$\int (\ln x)^2\,dx=x\big((\ln x)^2-2\ln x+2\big)+C.$$ Evaluate: at $x=e$ gives $e(1-2+2)=e$; at $x=1$ gives $1(0-0+2)=2$. So $\int_1^e (\ln x)^2\,dx=e-2$, hence $V=\pi(e-2)

title: 8.10-P2
text: The graph of the region bounded by $y=x^2$, $y=0$, and $x=2$ is shown in the figure labeled 8.10-P2. The region is revolved about the vertical line $x=3$. What is the volume of the resulting solid?
explanation: Rotate about $x=3$ (vertical), so use horizontal slices ($dy$) for washers. For a given $y$, the region runs from $x=\sqrt{y}$ to $x=2$ for $0\le y\le 4$. Outer radius: $R(y)=3-\sqrt{y}$, inner radius: $r(y)=3-2=1$. $$V=\pi\int_0^4\big(R(y)^2-r(y)^2\

title: 8.10-P3
text: The graph of the region bounded by $y=x^2$, $y=0$, $x=0$, and $x=1$ is shown in the figure labeled 8.10-P3. The region is revolved about the line $y=2$. What is the volume of the resulting solid?
explanation: Rotation about $y=2$ gives radius $r(x)=2-x^2$. $$V=\pi\int_0^1 (2-x^2)^2\,dx=\pi\int_0^1 (4-4x^2+x^4)\,dx =\pi\left[4x-\frac{4}{3}x^3+\frac{1}{5}x^5\right]_0^1 =\pi\left(4-\frac{4}{3}+\frac{1}{5}\right)=\frac{43\pi}{15}.$$

title: 8.11-P2
text: The region is bounded by $y=2x$ and $y=x^2$ for $0\le x\le 2$. The region is revolved about the $x$-axis. What is the volume?
explanation: Outer radius is $R(x)=2x$ and inner radius is $r(x)=x^2$ on $[0,2]$. $$V=\pi\int_0^2\left(R^2-r^2\right)dx=\pi\int_0^2(4x^2-x^4)\,dx.$$ $$\int_0^2(4x^2-x^4)\,dx=\left[\frac{4x^3}{3}-\frac{x^5}{5}\right]_0^2=\frac{32}{3}-\frac{32}{5}=\frac{64}{15}.$$

title: 8.11-P4
text: The region is bounded by $x=y^2$ and $x=4$ for $0\le y\le 2$. The region is revolved about the $y$-axis. What is the volume?
explanation: About the $y$-axis with $dy$: outer radius $R(y)=4$, inner radius $r(y)=y^2$. $$V=\pi\int_0^2\left(R^2-r^2\right)dy=\pi\int_0^2(16-y^4)\,dy.$$ $$\int_0^2(16-y^4)dy=\left[16y-\frac{y^5}{5}\right]_0^2=32-\frac{32}{5}=\frac{128}{5}.$$ So $V=\dfrac{128\p

title: 8.12-P1
text: The region bounded by $y=\sqrt{x}$ and $y=0$ for $0\le x\le 4$ is revolved about the line $y=1$. What is the volume?

title: 8.12-P3
text: The region bounded by $y=\ln x$ and $y=0$ for $1\le x\le e$ is revolved about the line $x=-1$. What is the volume?

title: 8.13-P1
text: The curve is given parametrically by $x=\cos t$ and $y=\sin t$ for $0\le t\le \frac{\pi}{2}$. The graph is shown in the figure labeled 8.13-P1. What is the exact arc length of the curve on this interv
explanation: Use parametric arc length: $$L=\int_{0}^{\frac{\pi}{2}}\sqrt{\left(\frac{dx}{dt}\right)^2+\left(\frac{dy}{dt}\right)^2}\,dt.$$ Here $\frac{dx}{dt}=-\sin t$ and $\frac{dy}{dt}=\cos t$, so the integrand is $\sqrt{\sin^2 t+\cos^2 t}=1$. Thus $$L=\int_0^

title: 8.13-P3
text: A particle moves along a line with velocity $v(t)$ shown in the figure labeled 8.13-P3. What is the total distance traveled from $t=0$ to $t=6$?
explanation: Total distance traveled is $$\int_0^6 |v(t)|\,dt.$$ From the graph: $v=2$ on $[0,2]$, $v=-1$ on $[2,4]$, and $v=0.5$ on $[4,6]$. So $$\int_0^2 2\,dt+\int_2^4 1\,dt+\int_4^6 0.5\,dt=4+2+1=7.$$

title: 9.0-UT-Q8
text: Refer to the figure (image). A particle has position $\vec r(t)=\langle t,\ t^2\rangle$ for $0\le t\le 2$. What is the slope $\dfrac{dy}{dx}$ of the path at $t=1$?
explanation: Here $x=t$ and $y=t^2$. Then $\frac{dx}{dt}=1$ and $\frac{dy}{dt}=2t$, so $$\frac{dy}{dx}=\frac{\frac{dy}{dt}}{\frac{dx}{dt}}=2t.$$ At $t=1$, the slope is $2$.

title: 9.0-UT-Q12
text: Refer to the polar graph (image) of $r=2+2\cos\theta$. What is the area enclosed by the curve?
explanation: Use $$A=\frac12\int_0^{2\pi} r^2\,d\theta=\frac12\int_0^{2\pi}(2+2\cos\theta)^2\,d\theta.$$ Expand: $(2+2\cos\theta)^2=4(1+2\cos\theta+\cos^2\theta)$, so $$A=2\int_0^{2\pi}(1+2\cos\theta+\cos^2\theta)\,d\theta.$$ Over $[0,2\pi]$, $\int_0^{2\pi}\cos\t

title: 9.0-UT-Q16
text: Refer to the figure (image). Let $C_1$ be $r=2\cos\theta$ and $C_2$ be $r=1$. What is the area of the region inside both curves?
explanation: Intersect when $2\cos\theta=1$, so $\theta=\pm\frac{\pi}{3}$. Inside both curves means $0\le r\le \min(1,2\cos\theta)$ for $\frac{-\pi}{2}\le\theta\le\frac{\pi}{2}$.\nThus $$A=\frac12\left(\int_{\frac{-\pi}{3}}^{\frac{\pi}{3}}1^2\,d\theta+2\int_{\fra

title: 9.1-P2
text: A curve is given parametrically by $x(t)=t^2+1$ and $y(t)=t^3-2t$. What is the equation of the tangent line when $t=1$?
explanation: Compute $\frac{dx}{dt}=2t$ and $\frac{dy}{dt}=3t^2-2$. At $t=1$, $m=\dfrac{\frac{dy}{dt}}{\frac{dx}{dt}}=\dfrac{1}{2}$. Also $(x(1),y(1))=(2,-1)$. Thus $y+1=\dfrac{1}{2}(x-2)$, so $y=\dfrac{1}{2}x-\dfrac{1}{2}$.

title: 9.1-P4
text: For $x(t)=e^t$ and $y(t)=e^{2t}$, what is $\dfrac{dy}{dx}$ in terms of $t$?
explanation: Use $\dfrac{dy}{dx}=\dfrac{\frac{dy}{dt}}{\frac{dx}{dt}}$. Here $\frac{dx}{dt}=e^t$ and $\frac{dy}{dt}=2e^{2t}$, so $\dfrac{dy}{dx}=\dfrac{2e^{2t}}{e^t}=2e^t$.

title: 9.3-P2
text: A curve is given by $x=t^2-1$ and $y=2t$ for $0\le t\le 2$. The graph of this parametric curve is provided.  ![9.3-P2](9.3-P2.png)  Which integral gives the arc length of the curve on $[0,2]$?
explanation: Use $s=\int_0^2 \sqrt{(\frac{dx}{dt})^2+(\frac{dy}{dt})^2}\,dt$. Here $\frac{dx}{dt}=2t$ and $\frac{dy}{dt}=2$, so $s=\int_0^2 \sqrt{4t^2+4}\,dt$.

title: 9.4-P4
text: The plane curve is $\mathbf{r}(t)=\langle \cos t, \tfrac12\sin(2t)\rangle$. A tangent direction at $t=\frac{\pi}{3}$ is shown.  ![9.4-P4](9.4-P4.png)  What is $\left.\dfrac{dy}{dx}\right|_{t=\frac{\pi
explanation: $\frac{dx}{dt}=-\sin t$ and $\frac{dy}{dt}=\cos(2t)$, so $\frac{dy}{dx}=\frac{\cos(2t)}{-\sin t}$. At $t=\frac{\pi}{3}$, this is $\frac{\frac{-1}{2}}{-\sqrt{3}/2}=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{3}$.

title: 9.7-P5
text: The image shows a polar graph. Which equation matches the graph?
explanation: The graph is symmetric about the polar axis and has a cusp at the origin, characteristic of a cardioid of the form $r=1+\cos\theta$.

title: 9.8-P5

text: Find the area of the region that lies inside $r=2+\cos\theta$ and outside $r=2$.

text: Find the area of the region that lies inside $r=3\sin\theta$ and outside $r=1$.
explanation: Intersections satisfy $3\sin\theta=1\Rightarrow \sin\theta=\tfrac{1}{3}$. Let $\alpha=\arcsin(\tfrac{1}{3})$, so the region occurs for $\theta\in[\alpha,\pi-\alpha]$. Area: $$A=\frac12\int_{\alpha}^{\pi-\alpha}\big((3\sin\theta)^2-1^2\big)\,d\theta =

title: 9.9-P3
text: Which integral gives the area of the region inside $r=1+\sin\theta$ and outside $r=1$, for $0\le \theta\le \pi$?
explanation: For area between polar curves on $[a,b]$, use $$A=\frac12\int_a^b\big(R(\theta)^2-r(\theta)^2\big)\,d\theta,$$ where $R$ is the outer radius. Here $R(\theta)=1+\sin\theta$ and $r(\theta)=1$ on $0\le\theta\le\pi$.

title: 9.9-P4
text: Find the area of the region that lies inside $r=4\cos\theta$ and outside $r=2$.
explanation: Intersect when $4\cos\theta=2\Rightarrow \cos\theta=\tfrac12$, so $\theta=\pm\tfrac{\pi}{3}$. Area: $$A=\frac12\int_{\frac{-\pi}{3}}^{\frac{\pi}{3}}\left((4\cos\theta)^2-2^2\right)d\theta =\frac12\int_{\frac{-\pi}{3}}^{\frac{\pi}{3}}(16\cos^2\theta-4

title: 9.9-P5
text: If a region is bounded between the outer polar curve $r=R(\theta)$ and the inner polar curve $r=r(\theta)$ for $\alpha\le\theta\le\beta$, which formula gives its area?
explanation: Polar area uses $A=\frac12\int r^2\,d\theta$. For the region between two curves, subtract the inner area from the outer area on the same $\theta$-interval: $$A=\frac12\int_{\alpha}^{\beta}\big(R(\theta)^2-r(\theta)^2\big)\,d\theta.$$

title: 10.1-P5
text: A student says: “The series $\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} a_n$ converges because the sequence $\{S_k\}$ is bounded.” Which additional condition, together with boundedness of $\{S_k\}$, would be sufficient to g
explanation: A bounded monotonic sequence converges. If the partial sums $\{S_k\}$ are bounded and increasing, then $S_k$ converges and the series converges.
options: A: $\{S_k\}$ is increasing. | B: $\{a_n\}$ is increasing. | C: $a_n>0$ for all $n$. | D: $S_k\ne 0$ for all $k$.

title: 10.13-P4
text: See image (10.13-P4). Which interval notation matches the interval shown?
explanation: An open circle means the endpoint is not included (parenthesis). A closed circle means included (bracket). The image shows open at $-2$ and closed at $3$, so the interval is $(-2,3]$.
